3 - How to use the lifelihood package

Source: vignettes/articles/3-how-to-use-lifelihood.qmd
3-how-to-use-lifelihood.qmd
If you haven’t already check it, have a look at:
  • what is the required data format to work with lifelihood?
  • setting up the configuration file

Load libraries 

# library(lifelihood)
devtools::load_all(compile = FALSE)
## ℹ Loading lifelihood

Data preparation

Load the dataset from .csv file:

# input data
df <- read.csv(here::here("data/fake_sample.csv"))
df$type <- as.factor(df$type)
df$geno <- as.factor(df$geno)
type geno sex_start sex_end sex mat_start mat_end clutch_start1 clutch_end1 clutch_size1 clutch_start2 clutch_end2 clutch_size2 mor_start mor_end
1 0 0 1000 0 0 1000 NA NA NA NA NA NA 0 1
2 0 0 1000 0 2 3 4 3 4 2 4 5 9 10
0 1 0 1000 0 3 4 2 4 5 NA NA NA 5 6
1 0 0 1000 0 0 1000 NA NA NA NA NA NA 0 1
2 1 0 1000 0 1 2 2 2 3 5 3 4 11 12
2 1 0 1000 0 1 2 2 2 1 5 8 3 14 20

Prepare input parameters for the lifelihoodData() function:

# name of the columns of the clutchs into a single vector
clutchs <- c(
  "clutch_start1", "clutch_end1", "clutch_size1",
  "clutch_start2", "clutch_end2", "clutch_size2"
)

Create the lifelihoodData object 

data <- lifelihoodData(
  df = df,
  sex = "sex",
  sex_start = "sex_start",
  sex_end = "sex_end",
  maturity_start = "mat_start",
  maturity_end = "mat_end",
  clutchs = clutchs,
  death_start = "mor_start",
  death_end = "mor_end",
  covariates = c("geno", "type"),
  model_specs = c("gam", "lgn", "wei")
)
summary(data)
##                      Length Class      Mode     
## df                   15     data.frame list     
## sex                   1     -none-     character
## sex_start             1     -none-     character
## sex_end               1     -none-     character
## maturity_start        1     -none-     character
## maturity_end          1     -none-     character
## clutchs               6     -none-     character
## death_start           1     -none-     character
## death_end             1     -none-     character
## model_specs           3     -none-     character
## covariates            2     -none-     character
## matclutch             1     -none-     logical  
## matclutch_size        0     -none-     NULL     
## right_censoring_date  1     -none-     numeric  
## critical_age          1     -none-     numeric  
## ratiomax              1     -none-     numeric

Get the results

All default parameters 

results <- lifelihood(
  lifelihoodData = data,
  path_config = here::here("config.yaml"),
  seeds = c(1, 2, 3, 4)
)
## Warning in check_valid_estimation(results_lifelihood = results): Estimation of
## 'increase_death_hazard' is close to the maximum bound:
## increase_death_hazard≃9.96964276246751. Consider increasing maximum bound.
## Warning in check_valid_estimation(results_lifelihood = results): Estimation of
## 'increase_tof_n_offspring' is close to the maximum bound:
## increase_tof_n_offspring≃9.9927346714109. Consider increasing maximum bound.
summary(results)
## LIFELIHOOD RESULTS
## 
## Likelihood:
## [1] -452.7831
## 
## Effects:
##                       name estimation stderror         metric        kind
## 1           int_expt_death -2.2970350        0     expt_death   intercept
## 2     eff_expt_death_geno1 -2.7198670        0     expt_death coefficient
## 3     eff_expt_death_type1 -2.8256645        0     expt_death coefficient
## 4     eff_expt_death_type2 -0.6237211        0     expt_death coefficient
## 5       int_survival_shape -3.1737311        0 survival_shape   intercept
## 6 eff_survival_shape_geno1  2.7688133        0 survival_shape coefficient

Get maximum likelihood found:

results$likelihood
## [1] -452.7831

Next step

Now that you have seen how to use the package, you can go further and customise your parameter boundaries and deal with estimation warnings.
